stem: A 68-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. His wife reports that he was fine this morning but started exhibiting these symptoms about an hour ago. His vital signs are: BP 180/100 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, RR 18 breaths/min, SpO2 95% on room air. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Identify the actions the nurse should take.

itemContext.sbar: S: Patient presents with sudden onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. B: History of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. A: BP 180/100 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, RR 18 breaths/min, SpO2 95% on room air. R: Patient requires immediate assessment and intervention for possible stroke.

rationale.correct: The patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms of a stroke. Rapid assessment and intervention are crucial to minimize brain damage. Actions such as notifying the healthcare provider, preparing for thrombolytic therapy, and monitoring neurological status are essential.
rationale.incorrect: Delaying notification of the healthcare provider or failing to monitor neurological status can lead to irreversible brain damage. Administering oral medications or providing food/fluids could be dangerous if the patient has impaired swallowing.
clinicalPearls: Time is brain in stroke management.
Rapid assessment and intervention are critical.
Monitor for changes in neurological status.
rationale.questionTrap: The question focuses on prioritizing immediate actions in a stroke scenario. Students may be tempted to choose actions that are important but not the most immediate.

responseOptions.text: Provide the patient with a sip of water to help with swallowing.
Elevate the head of the bed to 30 degrees.
Obtain a STAT CT scan of the head.

columns.text: Elevate the head of the bed to 30 degrees.
Obtain a STAT CT scan of the head.
